person_003.name: WilliamAllen
person_003.description: Allen was a Quaker who worked in the pharmaceutical industry. Davy asked him to give lectures on natural philosophy at the RI. FRSL.

person_368.name: Horace Bénédict deSaussure
person_368.description: Genevan geologist, meteorologist, physicist, mountaineer and Alpine expolorer. Often referred to as the founder of Alpinism and modern meteorology.

person_066.name: JohnDalton
person_066.description: Mancunian chemist and natural philosopher who lectured at the Royal Institution. He formulated a version of the atomic theory of matter much disliked by Davy. FRSL.

person_030.name: Antoine-LaurentLavoisier
person_030.description: French chemist and tax farmer (for which he was guillotined). Developed a new nomenclature for chemistry (much of which is still in use today) and argued strongly against the existence of phlogiston. Davy read some of his writings while in Cornwall which he then opposed and throughout his career maintained an ambivalent attitude towards Lavoisierian chemisty. ForMemRSL.

person_016.name: JosephPriestley
person_016.description: Unitarian and political radical forced into exile in Pennsylvania. As a natural philospher and chemist who retained belief in phlogiston, he discovered oxygen and nitrous oxide though not under those names. FRSL.

person_331.name: Christoph HeinrichPfaff
person_331.description: German physician, chemist and physicist who worked on animal electricity alongside Volta and Humboldt. The younger brother of mathematician Johann Friedrich Pfaff.

person_199.name: AlessandroVolta
person_199.description: Professor of experimental physics at the University of Pavia. At the end of the eighteenth century he Invented the Voltaic pile which produced electric current and which Davy shortly dubbed the battery. Davy described meeting him in 1814 in notebook 14/I, p.38. ForMemRSL.

person_603.name: Antonio deMarti Franques
person_603.description: Catalan chemist who also worked in geology and mereorology amongst other disciplines.

person_163.name: Thomas CharlesHope
person_163.description: Professor of Medicine and Chemistry at Edinburgh University. Discovered the element strontium and seems to have played a role in Davy's appointment to the Royal Institution. FRSL.

person_271.name: Alexander vonHumboldt
person_271.description: German geographer, naturalist and explorer. ForMemRSL.

person_226.name: ThomasThomson
person_226.description: Scottish chemist and mineralogist whose writings contributed to the early spread of Dalton's atomic theory. FRSL.

person_616.name: Théodore Turquet deMayerne
person_616.description: Genevean born physician who worked in France and England, where he was royal physician for which he was knighted.

person_021.name: StephenHales
person_021.description: English clergyman who made major contributions to a range of scientific fields including botany, pneumatic chemistry and physiology.  FRSL.

person_026.name: HenryCavendish
person_026.description: A central figure in English natural philosophy and chemistry, among other research he determined the density of the earth and discovered what would later be named hydrogen. He was one of the people who helped appoint Davy to the Royal Institution. Following his death in 1810 Davy delivered a widely-quoted eulogy on Cavendish and later arranged for some of his apparatus to be transferred to the Royal Institution. FRSL.

place_222.description: The world's second-largest and second-most populous continent.

place_569.name: Sicily
place_569.description: Sicily is the largest and most populous island in the Mediterranean Sea and one of the twenty regions of Italy.

place_071.name: London
place_071.description: The capital city of England and the United Kingdom.
